After the Punic triumphs, the matrons of Rome aspired to the common benefits of a free and opulent republic: their wishes were gratified by the indulgence of fathers and lovers, and their ambition was unsuccessfully refisted by the gravity of Cato the Censor¹²⁰. They declined the solemnities of the old nupdals, defeated the an- nual prescription by an absence of three days, and, without lofing their name or independence, subscribed the liberal and definite terms of a marriage-contract.
